nodes.text: Intergenerational mobility in the United States varies geographically and this spatial variation is systematically associated with observable area characteristics
We measure mobility using administrative federal tax records for more than 40 million children and their parents (1996–2012) and define child and parent family incomes using multi-year averages

We prefer a rank-rank specification (child percentile rank regressed on parent percentile rank) because the conditional expectation of child rank given parent rank is almost perfectly linear and rank-rank estimates are robust
Canonical log-log IGE estimates are unstable in these data because the log-log relationship is nonlinear and sensitive to treatment of zero or very small incomes

National rank-rank result: a 10 percentile increase in parent income rank is associated with a 3.41 percentile increase in child income rank on average; college attendance and teenage birth rates are linearly related to parent rank (10 ppts -> +6.7 pp college, -3 pp teenage birth)

Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across commuting zones (CZs); example: probability of bottom-quintile child reaching national top quintile is 4.4% in Charlotte versus 12.9% in San Jose

Within CZs the rank-rank relationship is nearly linear and summarized by slope (relative mobility) and intercept (absolute outcomes); absolute upward mobility defined as expected child rank at parent percentile 25 (r25)

Spatial patterns: relative mobility lowest in Southeast, highest in Mountain West and rural Midwest; absolute upward mobility (r25) ranges notably across CZs (e.g., 35.8 to 46.2 among 50 largest CZs); CZ quality accounts for substantial variation in expected ranks for low-income children (1 SD CZ quality ≈ 0.20 SD child rank)

Intermediate outcomes follow spatial patterns of income mobility: college attendance, college quality rank, and teenage birth rates by parent rank vary across CZs in ways closely correlated with income mobility, implying much heterogeneity emerges before labor-market entry
Cross-country comparison using rank-rank slopes: U.S. slope ~0.341, Denmark ~0.180, Canada ~0.174, indicating substantially lower relative mobility in the U.S.

Five CZ-level factors are strongly correlated with lower upward mobility: (i) greater residential segregation, (ii) greater income inequality (especially within bottom 99%), (iii) worse K–12 school outputs conditional on income, (iv) weaker social capital, and (v) weaker family stability (higher single-parent share)

Selected correlations/evidence: fraction of children with single parents correlates ≈ -0.76 with r25; Gini coefficient for parent income correlates ≈ -0.578 with r25; racial segregation index correlates ≈ -0.361 with r25; income segregation of poverty (bottom quartile) has a strong negative association with r25

Multivariable CZ regressions: the five factors jointly explain a large share of CZ-level variance in absolute upward mobility (high R-squared), and results are robust to state fixed effects though variables are endogenous so not causal estimates

Conclusions and limitations: the analysis documents large, robust within-country spatial heterogeneity in mobility and strong correlations with local conditions but is descriptive; causal mechanisms are not identified and variables are endogenously determined
